utterances: Last week, Boris Staparac unveiled his creation - a nearly 10-foot statue of Sylvester Stallone, a.k.a.
Rocky, overlooking the village with hands raised in victory.
(Soundbite of movie, ""Rocky"")
(As Rocky Balboa) (unintelligible).
I did it.
For photos of the statue, go to npr.org.
If you've been to Philadelphia, you may notice a resemblance.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Robert Siegel.

Here are some readers' comments to an article that's online today, an article which claims that, and I quote, ""cracks are beginning to appear with many analysts and political experts questioning the official story about 9/11.
A reader from Canada named Noor(ph) cites a Canadian documentary and writes, ""The Twin Towers bombings were pre-planned.
It all happened because of some quarter's hatred for the Muslims in the U.S.
and the UK.
A reader named Lane from Germany adds this, ""Few believe the Towers were done by CIA.
They're convinced that Bush and the Jews let it happen so they could finally attack the oil reserves.
And Ab(ph) from the UK calls for an independent inquiry into 9/11 carried out by experts from different countries.
Of the American version of events, Ab writes, ""It don't add up.

There is a body of opinion, especially among Muslims, that the 9/11 Commission notwithstanding and videos purporting to show Osama bin Laden proudly taking credit notwithstanding, there is a body of opinion that bin Laden, al-Qaida and a couple of dozen young Arab men did not fly into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on September 11, 2001.
How many people regard that basic plot outline as a fraud?
Well, Andy Kohut, who is director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, once put this question to Muslims in several countries.
Do you believe that groups of Arabs carried out the attacks against the United States on September 11, or don't you believe this?
What kind of answers did you get?
Surprisingly, we had an overwhelming number of people say no, they did not carry out these attacks.
In Indonesia, 65 percent said no. In Egypt, 59 percent.
Turkey, 59 percent.

In each of the five Muslim countries in which we conducted a survey, majorities said no. In Europe, among four different sub-populations of Muslims, majorities said no. And in Nigeria, the only place where there was even close to an even division of opinion about this.
I was flummoxed by this question.
It's one that the Gallup organization had asked in January of 2002 soon after the attacks.

And I put it on our questionnaire just to check whether Muslims had a different view and it surprised me that they were as much of the view that this did not happen or that Arabs did not carry out these attacks as they were back then.
How recently have you seen figures like that showing majorities of opinion in various Muslim countries not believing that Arab young men carried out 9/11?
Well, this survey was conducted only a few months ago.
It was conducted in April and May, so this is pretty much current opinion.
Andrew Kohut, thanks a lot for talking with us about it.
You're quite welcome.
That's Andrew Kohut of the Pew Center speaking to us from Washington.
Now to Ayman Safadi, who is editor of the newspaper Al Ghad in Amman, Jordan.
Mr.

Safadi, when we hear these poll results which imply that people in countries like yours, the majority of them don't believe in the basic plot line of 9/11 as Americans understand it, what should we think?
Well, I would tend to think that the position of people has changed.

Initially, you did have people who sort of said it could not have been al-Qaida who was behind those terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, but I think now, the majority of the people, based on our own reporting and our reading of the situation, do believe that al-Qaida was behind it.
And Osama bin Laden came out publicly and admitted to have been responsible for the attacks.
However, you do have a number of complex issues that come to play whenever it comes to situations regarding al-Qaida relations with the West, relations with America and Israel.
Part of it is probably a conspiracy theory.

This is a part of the world where conspiracy theories abound and it could be explained in a culture of escapism somehow that people do not want to come to terms with the harshness of their reality and therefore they escape into conspiracy theories whereby they try to blame a lot of problems that happen onto others.

The other part is probably - it's a defensive position whereby people feel that the accusation of al-Qaida as being behind the attack is a ticket for the West, America in particular, to launch a war on terror, which we understand, a lot of people understand, as a war on their identity and their culture.

So if I understand you right, among the 53 percent of the Jordanians who are asked the question do you believe that groups of Arabs carried out the 9/11 attacks or don't believe it - 53 percent said they don't believe that.
You would say some of those people might in fact believe it but might for other purposes not say that at that moment?

That's correct, because I think the response would probably be rooted in them fearing that their answer would be used to justify the war on terror and I think the war on terror has failed in trying to convince Arabs and Muslims that it's a war that will serve their common interests because terrorism is the enemy of Islam as much as it is the enemy of the West.

So probably they're afraid that the West will try and use this information to justify the war on terror and probably expand it and probably expand it and probably threaten more their culture and identity.
Okay.
Broadcasting from Southern California and Washington, D.C., its MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
It's MORNING EDITION, from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep, along South Asia's Grand Trunk Road, where one journey ends and another begins in this hour.
I'm Lynn Neary.

Long-time Senator Jim Bunning is not running reelection, but the Republican establishment's choice, Trey Grayson, is under assault from first-time candidate Rand Paul, who is backed by Tea Party supporters.
It's lunchtime at the MJ Family Restaurant in Edmonton, Kentucky, a tiny town in the South Central part of the state, and Rand Paul has brought his appetite.
Unidentified Man: Yeah, they got some really good food here.
And while the fried catfish is pretty tasty, it's the appearance of Rand Paul that has brought Edmonton trucker Charlie Costello by.
I'm supporting Rand Paul because he is a fresh face in politics and is one of the people, and not one of the career politicians.
And besides, almost everything he believes and says is things that I have believed and said for years and years.
I'm just glad we finally got somebody that thinks like I do.
Unidentified Man: Disastrous bailouts, busted budgets, the health care takeover: Big government is out of control.
(SOUNDBITE OF POLITICAL ADVERTISEMENT)
Paul has presented himself as someone who is willing to go to Washington and shake things up to challenge the status quo.
That's Al Cross, director of the Center for Rural Journalism at the University of Kentucky.
Even among Republicans, there's a substantial part of the electorate who aren't all that happy with the Republican establishment, Mitch McConnell being the chief example.
McConnell is the state's senior senator and Senate minority leader.
He was instrumental in persuading - some might say forcing - Bunning not to run for another term, and he's thrown his political muscle and organization behind Secretary of State Trey Grayson.
(SOUNDBITE OF POLITICAL ADVERTISEMENT)
I'm Senator Mitch McConnell.
I rarely endorse in primaries, but these are critical times.
President Obama's spending threatens to destroy more jobs.
I know Trey Grayson and trust him.
We need Trey's conservative leadership to help turn back the Obama agenda.
You know, I love meeting my Facebook.
I thought I recognized your face with the - and the name.
But...
Trey Grayson has been touring Kentucky in the final days of the campaign in an RV, meeting Facebook friends and selling himself as a conservative who can work with others.
I'm not going to be the guy who's going to go up there and hold press conferences and jump on talk radio and yell and scream and make a lot of noise and vote no and not accomplish anything.
I'm going to go up there, I'm going to work with Republicans and work with Democrats when I can, and get stuff done.

But in this year of the Tea Party, working with Democrats to get stuff done is viewed with suspicion, and making a lot of noise is what many Republican voters seem to want most: a sentiment pretty in tune with Rand Paul.
We win things, not necessarily.
But I think we've already gotten some national attention, but I think we will have a pulpit.
If we use it effectively, we may be able to change things in our country.
